title: Single-cell isolation from full-thickness human intestinal tissue resections for single-cell RNA sequencing

Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1] provides an easy-to-follow flowchart of the protocol.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3100-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Flowchart outlining the steps involved in the protocol
EC/LP, epithelial cells/lamina propria; MUS, muscle; EM, enzyme mix; CM, complete media; HBSS, Hank’s buffered salt solution; DTT, Dithiothreitol; RBC, red blood cells.
Pre-processing of specimen
Timing: 10 min
Preprocessing of complete full thickness tissue specimen.
Rinse tissue thoroughly with chilled HBSS.
Place complete full thickness tissue on staging board, mucosal side up (serosal side down), gently blot with paper towels, alternate rinsing and blotting.
Note: Do not drag the paper towel across the mucosal side of the specimen.
Keep the specimen wet, rinsing and blotting until the tissue is visibly clean of blood, debris and mucus.
Work gently, and quickly.
Place the blotted tissue on clean paper towels, straighten it making sure all layers are distinguishable,
Note: perform as efficiently as possible, do not let tissue dry.
Tissue should be rinsed and blotted within 10 min.
Working quickly ensures the highest viability of all cell populations.
Epithelial/lamina propria layer isolation
Timing: 2 h
Isolation of lamina propria layer from intestinal tissue.
Dissect the specimen after the picture is taken. The steps below are an example for processing a full thickness tissue segment.
Lamina propria layer (avoid the inclusion any muscle or fat tissue).
Using curved, round-ended scissors, press down while “lightly pinching” the lamina propria with forceps.
Cut strips by gently bearing down on the scissors at the deepest part of their curve (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]). Avoid cutting into the muscularis propria.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3100-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Illustration showing the proper placement of bent-tip forceps and scissors to remove epithelial layer from intestinal tissue
Cut at least four to six strips of at least 2 cm length each.

Note: Smaller samples can be used but are not as easy to manipulate and give lower numbers of cells. This is particularly important when considering the cell populations associated with different levels of inflammation in IBD.
The enzymes solutions here were used for samples up to 2 g per enzyme solution.
Transfer strips to a 100 mm Falcon petri dish with HBSS to prevent tissue from drying.
The above strips are used for epithelial (EC) and lamina propria (LP) fraction isolation.
Remove muscle tissue with scalpel (avoid fat). Proceed to "Muscular Layer Isolation".
Transfer lamina propria strips to a small weigh boat. Weigh the strips and record the weight.
Incubate strips in DTT (75 mg of DTT in 50 mL of HBSS), stirring only fast enough to keep the strips from settling, for 30 min at RT.
Cover DTT cup with the lid.
Set the speed of stirrer to achieve slow stirring.
After 30 minutes, use forceps to remove strips from DTT and transfer to a 100 mm Falcon Petri dish with 10 mL of HBSS. Rinse thoroughly.
Using forceps, transfer tissue strips to 10 mL EM1-A tube (contains the enzyme).
Incubate for 30 min at 37°C bath, invert for 10 s every 5 min.
Filter EM1-A through 100 μm cell strainer filter.
Transfer the partially digested tissue from the top of the strainer to the EM1-B tube (Contains 10 mL). Incubate EM1-B tube at 37 for 30 min (as in step 10a). Proceed with EM1-B in step 16.
Spin the filtrate at 330 × g for 5 min, 4°C and resuspend pellet in 5 mL complete media.
Take 40 μL of EM1-A cell suspension and mix with 40 μL of Trypan Blue.
Count cells using a hemacytometer and record the cell number and viability.

Leave the rest of cell suspension of EM1-A on ice.
After counting, proceed to “RBC LYSIS PROTOCOL”. After red cell lysis, count cells again.
Note: This is final count, and the fraction is labeled EC-LP1.
Transfer strips from step 10 to EM1-B tube (containing the enzyme) and incubate as in step 10a.
After 30 min, filter through 100 μm cell strainer.
Centrifuge the filtrate at 330 × g, 5 min, 4°C and resuspend the pellet in 5 mL of complete media.
Remove 40 μL of EM1-B cell suspension, mix with 40 μL of Trypan Blue and count cell number and viability.
After counting proceed to “RBC LYSIS PROTOCOL”.
Note: This fraction is now called EC-LP2.
After RBC lysis, re-suspend the cell pellet in 5 mL of complete media and count cell number/cell viability again (RBC contamination should drop dramatically).
Note: The cell number and cell viability are final values for EC-LP2.
Critical: Frothing can be avoided by slowly resuspending the cells, and not allowing bubbles to be introduced during mixing. Time of digestion can be variable but must be constantly monitored, as over- or under-digestion will affect cell yield, quality and viability by live/ dead counts as indicated by trypan blue exclusion. Final tissue digest should be carefully evaluated for visual appearance (should be viscous, with fibrous threads, and devoid of any obvious tissue chunks) (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).

Figure 3. Appearance of undigested, under-digested and fully digested tissue
Muscular layer isolation
Timing: 2 h
Isolation of muscle layer from intestinal tissue.
Muscular layer isolation is performed in parallel with EC isolation.
Weigh the amount of muscle tissue in a small weigh boat and record it.
At least 2–3 g are needed get enough single cells from the muscle layer for 10× Genomics protocol.

Transfer the muscle to a 100 mm Falcon petri dish.
Although no infectious tissue is ever used in this study, all steps are carried out in a BSL2 biosafety cabinet to minimize biohazard safety exposure.
Using #21 curved scalpel blade, mince the tissue, with a rocking motion.
Critical: Do not drag the scalpel blade to “tear” the tissue. Cuts should be very clean with the rocking motion of the blade. The easiest method to mince the tissue in this way is to cut strips.
Cut the strips into small squares or approximately 2 mm2. Pile the small squares up and mince with the rocking blade motion.
Transfer the minced tissue from the petri dish to the 50 mL conical tube containing 10 mL of collagenase II (2 mg/mL), 2.5% PSF in RPMI (EM3).
Use a small amount (about 2–3 mL) of collagenase II solution to rinse the petri dish and add back to the tube.
Incubate at 37°C for 60 min. Invert tube continuously for 30 s every 15 min.
After 60 min, filter through a 100 μm pore filter.
Transfer the partially digested tissue to a petri dish containing 10 mL of (enzyme free) complete media.
Incubate for 30 min at 37°C under 5% CO2.
Centrifuge the filtrate solution (330 × g, 5 min, and 4°C), and re-suspend the pellet in ∼5 mL of complete media.
Note: Keep on ice until the retained fraction is finished incubating.
After 30-min incubation from 26a, filter through 100 μm pore cell strainer.
Centrifuge at 330 × g, 4°C.
Resuspend pellet in complete media and combine with muscle filtrate fraction from step 27.
Count the cell number and viability of the muscle fraction (pooled) by combining 40 μL of the cell suspension and 40 μL of trypan blue.

Remove red blood cells using “RBC LYSIS PROTOCOL”.
Count cell number and viability and label MUS.
RBC lysis
Timing: 30 min
Removal of red blood cells (RBCs) from isolated single cell suspension.
Bring the cell suspension from the ice bucket to the centrifuge and spin (330 × g, 5 min, 4°C).
Re-suspend the pellet in working solution at 2 million cells/mL of working solution.
Incubate with RBC buffer 5 min at 25°C.
Add 2× volume of complete media to halt lysis, centrifuge (330 × g, 5 min, 4°C), wash two additional times with 10-mL cold HBSS.
After final wash, re-suspend the pellet in 5 mL of complete media and count.
Methanol fixation of isolated single cells
Timing: 10 min
Fixation of isolated single cells for storage and subsequent analysis.
Centrifuge 0.1–1.0 × 106 cells in 15 mL round bottom culture tubes at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
The exact cell number you fix is solely dependent on how many cells are obtained from each layer, ensuring multiple aliquots for each layer are prepared.
Remove the supernatant without disrupting the cell pellet and add 1 mL chilled 1× PBS (Media Core #121–1000) using a wide-bore pipette tip (MBP #3531).
Gently pipette 10 times mixing until the cells are completely suspended. Spin the suspension at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Repeat above two steps (step 38 and 39).
Remove the supernatant without disrupting the cell pellet.
Add 200 μL chilled 1X PBS using a wide-bore pipette tip and gently pipette the mixture 10 times or until cells are completely suspended.
Add 800 μL chilled 100% methanol drop by drop to the 200 μL cell suspension in the tube while gently mixing on a vortex (at the lowest speed setting). This prevents cells from clumping.

Store cells at −20°C for 30 min, then transfer to −80°C for long-term storage (several months).
Pause point: Methanol-fixed isolated cells can be stored until needed for scRNA-seq analysis.
Viability assessment based on dye exclusion and apoptosis
Timing: 30 min
Quality of the isolated cells (after single cell isolation and before fixation) can be assessed by Trypan blue staining. As a quality control measure, flow cytometry analysis can be performed with cells stained with annexin V and propidium iodide (PI).
Wash cells twice with cold PBS and then resuspend cells in 1× Binding Buffer at a concentration of 1 × 106 cells/mL.
Transfer 100 μL of the solution (1 × 105 cells) to a 5 mL culture tube.
Add 5 μL of FITC Annexin V and 5 μL PI.
Gently vortex the cells and incubate for 15 min at 25°C in the dark.
Add 400 μL of 1× Binding Buffer to each tube. Analyze by flow cytometry within 1 h.
Single cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq)
Isolated single cells can be processed and analyzed for scRNA-seq using 10× Chromium kit (following manufacturers’ instructions and as outlined in our publication).1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
